-------- Original Message --------

Hi Lucas,

You've taken the first step towards becoming a game developer, which is
*choosing* to become a game developer.  With determination, know that you
will get there.

My first recommendation is to pick up a copy of "Get in the Game!", by Marc
Mencher.  Most of the suggestions I will be making come from this book.
Follow this book closely and you'll be much better off.  When he says to
build a contact database, don't say to yourself, "Oh, that's a good idea,"
but then never get around to doing it.  Actually do it!

To help focus your resum�, you should start out with a short cover letter
aimed specifically at the company where you are applying for a position.
First, do a little research about the company and try to find out the name
of the person you will be addressing this letter to.  

Start out with an energetic statement about who you are and why you
*specifically* like their company.  List the *specific* position you are
applying for and list three of the qualifications that fit best for *this*
job.  Use bullet points for your qualifications so they stand out from the
rest of the letter.  That way, if an HR manager were scanning your cover
letter, then they'd see your qualifications immediately.  Close with a
paragraph inviting them to look at your resum� and an enclosed CD-ROM of
your *best* work.  Leave a phone number and time that they can reach you.
Finally, list a specific date or time period that you will contact them if
you have not heard from them beforehand.  If you need an example of a cover
letter, e-mail me off the list and I'll send you a copy.

I suggest keeping your resum� to one-page if you are entry-level, unless you
wrote an optimized NVIDIA driver for Linux from scratch in your spare time.


Start off the page with the usual contact information and immediately below
list the title *exactly* as it was listed on their website, want-ad, etc.
In regards to your question about being self-taught, you should definitely
list all your *applicable* skills for the position.  List these right at the
top of your resume in bullet form before you go into further detail.  Until
recently, it has been accepted in the industry that most of the skills
needed for game development are self-taught.  However, some schools are
starting to offer classes on topics such as AI, Game Design, Graphics, etc.


In a new section, list your experience in chronological form.  If your paid
jobs have nothing to do with game development or are a stretch, then don't
list them.  Instead list your game or programming projects that you
completed in school.  Elaborate on the list of skills you mentioned at the
top of your resum�.

Third, have a separate section for education listing the degree you received
and any additional information that elicits your performance in college
(e.g. graduating with high honors).  Also, you can list the relevant course
topics you took under this section.

Lastly, list one or two references, that you have *contacted* beforehand.
Give them a call and ask them questions such as, "What is one quality that I
have and one area that you think I could work on?"  Hopefully, they will
give you an honest response.  This will help you gauge whether they would be
a good reference to list.

The most important part is to keep the attention of your reader focused.
Remember that a resum�, if effective, gets you a phone call and not the job
itself.  *You* are whats going to get the job after you talk with them on
the phone and they see how great a fit you would be to their team.

Take the time to prepare a CD-ROM if you have good demos to show off and
make sure they are easy to run/install.  If you are going to submit most of
your applications electronically, then create a website where those demos
can be downloaded.

Instead of sending out a resum� to anybody and everybody, narrow a list down
to a small number of companies that you really want to work for.  This
enthusiasm you have for their company will show naturally when corresponding
with HR.

And as you probably already know: network, network, network.  Make sure all
your family, friends, friends of friends, friends of family know that you
*are* a game developer.  One day your grandmother will be playing a card
game with her friends and she'll find out that someone's grandson works in
the video game industry.  Next thing you know, you'll be having lunch with
them and building a solid contact in the game industry.

And by all means, keep working on small games in your free time to hone
those skills.

Best of luck,
Amir
